title: What will happen when you have two CPUs in your computer? - Quora

response.answer_text: From a logical perspective nothing special multiple CPU’s provided that all have unrestricted access to the whole of main memory are no different from the system perspective to a multi-core system with a single chip. Things do get more complex if subgroups of processors have dedicated memory not accessible to other processors, though this too is actually a situation that every modern mobile phone, laptop or desktop has, it has at least two core subgroups of processors with separate memory systems the CPU and GPU. In the second case each is in effect it’s own computer, with it’s own CPU, RAM and IO interfaces. That said these can still be merged and used together to solve any parallel task it just requires a more advanced scheduler and more complex memory management to ensure synchronisation of shared memory etc.

Servers. That's about it. Mostly two CPUs are useful when you have a lot of seperate tasks that need to be executed in parallel. See while different cores in the same CPU can talk to each other quickly talking to a seperate CPU (for CPUs that even allow it) is SLOW. Seperate tasks make inter-CPU communication less likely, so it's less of a bottleneck. Multi CPU designs have fallen somewhat out of favor as CPUs with previously unimaginable numbers of cores like the AMththreadrippers have come out. When one CPU can have 64 cores, having two just is not something most applications require.

I already have four CPUs in my computer. Because they are all in one chip they are called cores. But in the past, there have been plenty of computers with multiple separated CPUs. They just make your computer go faster in many, but not all, circumstances.

Increasing parallelism which allows more flexibility to an enterprise. Besides a smaller footprint, the power and environmental costs are reduced. While there may be talk of multiple cores the reality is that modern systems are quite sophisticated and large. http://www.redbooks.ibm.com/redbooks/pdfs/sg248851.pdf

If by CPU you mean cores it is in every computer these days. Be it your mobile or computer. They are handled and tasks are allocated accordingly by a controller and run in smooth sync. But if you mean CPU as in physical processor it requires a special motherboard that supports two physical processor which is costlier because the mobo takes care of routing data from ram to two processor based on availability the processor sholud be selected for a particular job and scheduling, parllel programming ,shared memory, message passing all is taken care. Consider you have two quad core processor running with hyper threading so each processor has 8 threads now you get 8 x 2 = 16 threads!! That is a lot of computing power.

Pretty much all CPU’s these days are multi-core, which effectively means there are multiple CPU’s on the same chip. Multiple CPU’s works the same way, except they’re in different sockets and there’s usually no shared cache.
